ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Caudal (posterior) cerebellar syndrome
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by central oculomotor findings (failure of visual fixation suppression, direction-changing/rebound nystagmus, impaired pursuit, absent OKN) with normal peripheral vestibular function and relative sparing of extremity ataxia.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Rostral (anterior) cerebellar syndrome
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initial diagnosis based on history, but less likely given the specific oculomotor deficits and lack of significant limb ataxia observed during vestibular assessment.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Peripheral vestibular dysfunction
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out by normal caloric responses, normal rotary chair SHA/gain, and normal VOR gain.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing status as part of the comprehensive evaluation.
To assess functional balance and sensory integration.
To evaluate the vestibulo-ocular reflex and visual-vestibular interaction.
To assess central vestibular and oculomotor function.
Follow-up after 1 year to rule out progressive disorder.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry was normal. Vestibular testing revealed normal peripheral function (calorics, rotary chair VOR/SHA) but significant central signs including failure of visual fixation suppression, direction-changing and rebound gaze-evoked nystagmus, impaired pursuit, and absent OKN. Functional balance (CDP) showed falls in vestibular-dependent conditions. Findings are consistent with a caudal cerebellar syndrome.

tests.name: Computerized Dynamic Posturography (CDP)
tests.result_summary: Motor Control normal with rightward weight symmetry. SOT abnormal with falls in conditions 5 and 6.

tests.name: Rotary Chair Testing
tests.result_summary: Normal SHA and VOR gain. Abnormal Visual Fixation Suppression (high failure gains 0.36-0.40). Low normal step velocity.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Oculomotor
tests.result_summary: Spontaneous up-beating nystagmus; direction-changing and rebounding gaze-evoked nystagmus; saccade undershoots; cogwheeling pursuit; absent horizontal OKN.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Caloric
tests.result_summary: Normal labyrinthine function (UW 6%, DP 6%); failure of visual fixation suppression (78% left cool, 67% right warm).

tests.name: VEMPs
tests.result_summary: Cervical and ocular VEMPs without repeatable waveforms.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up testing 1 year later showed results equivalent to the initial exam, ruling out a progressive disorder. Saccadic inaccuracies improved slightly but remained asymmetric; other central signs (fixation suppression failure, poor OKN) remained unchanged.

tests.name: Comprehensive Vestibular Assessment (Repeat)
tests.result_summary: Results equivalent to initial exam. Saccadic inaccuracies improved to marginally normal but remained asymmetric. Abnormal fixation suppression and poor OKN unchanged.

proposed_items: Referral to physical therapy for balance rehabilitation assessment and treatment.
Referral to recreational therapy program for education, counseling, and strength/conditioning.
Return to clinic in 1 year to rule out progressive component.
counseling_actions: Explain that the inner ear balance sensors are working normally.
Clarify that the difficulty lies in the brain's central processing (cerebellum) of balance signals.
Advise caution when turning or changing positions quickly to prevent falls.
Discuss that physical therapy can help develop strategies to manage symptoms.

escalation.rationale_short: For balance rehabilitation to address functional deficits caused by central vestibular dysfunction.

follow_up_plan.objective: To monitor stability of the condition and rule out any progressive component.

expected_outcome: Initial consultation for balance rehabilitation was recommended, but not completed.
Patient returned to the clinic in a year and the results ruled out any progressive component of the initial findings.
